english: Indicates something just happened: “have just done; very recently did.” Attach to the past plain form (Vた・Aかった・Nだった + ばかり).
japanese_example: <ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby><ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べたばかりだ。

english: Means “only; nothing but,” emphasizing that almost everything is X (often with a negative nuance depending on context). Attach to nouns or the plain form as appropriate.
japanese_example: <ruby>甘<rt>あま</rt></ruby>い<ruby>物<rt>もの</rt></ruby>ばかり<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べている。

english: Means “merely because; just because,” where that reason leads to an unfortunate result. Attach to the plain form (Vる/Vた/Aい/Aかった/Nな/Nだった + ばかりに).
japanese_example: <ruby>知<rt>し</rt></ruby>らなかったばかりに、<ruby>行<rt>い</rt></ruby>けなかった。
english_example: Just because I didn’t know, I couldn’t go.

english: A rough/masculine (often dialectal) form meaning “won’t forgive/allow,” equivalent to 許さない. Used in strong, blunt statements.
japanese_example: <ruby>今回<rt>こんかい</rt></ruby>は<ruby>許<rt>ゆる</rt></ruby>さん。
english_example: I won’t forgive you this time.

english: Town; city; an urban area or downtown. Often used with へ/に to mean going out into town.
japanese_example: <ruby>街<rt>まち</rt></ruby>へ<ruby>出<rt>で</rt></ruby>る。

english: Menacing intensity; a scary edge or intimidating force (often from someone’s eyes, voice, or presence).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>目<rt>め</rt></ruby>に<ruby>凄<rt>すご</rt></ruby>みがある。
english_example: There’s a menacing intensity in his eyes.

english: To make something work effectively; to apply/bring out an effect (e.g., voice, wit, intimidation). Often appears as Nに〜を利かせる.
japanese_example: <ruby>声<rt>こえ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>迫力<rt>はくりょく</rt></ruby>を<ruby>利<rt>き</rt></ruby>かせた。
english_example: He put force into his voice.

english: To put on a menacing air; to make one’s intimidation felt (by eyes, tone, attitude, etc.). Commonly used toward a target with に.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はハリーに<ruby>凄<rt>すご</rt></ruby>みを<ruby>利<rt>き</rt></ruby>かせた。
english_example: He put on a menacing air toward Harry.

english: Cleaning (noun); with する it means “to clean.” Common pattern: 場所を掃除する.
japanese_example: <ruby>部屋<rt>へや</rt></ruby>を<ruby>掃除<rt>そうじ</rt></ruby>する。

english: Hindrance; disturbance; nuisance. Often as 邪魔をする (“to get in the way; to bother”) and 邪魔だ (“in the way”).
japanese_example: <ruby>邪魔<rt>じゃま</rt></ruby>をするな。

english: Back door; rear entrance (as opposed to 正面玄関/表口).
japanese_example: <ruby>裏口<rt>うらぐち</rt></ruby>から<ruby>入<rt>はい</rt></ruby>る。
english_example: I enter through the back door.

english: Garden; yard (the outdoor area around a house).
japanese_example: <ruby>庭<rt>にわ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>遊<rt>あそ</rt></ruby>ぶ。

english: Dazzling; glaring; so bright it hurts the eyes. Used for sunlight, lights, and sometimes figuratively for “brilliant.”
japanese_example: <ruby>太陽<rt>たいよう</rt></ruby>が<ruby>眩<rt>まぶ</rt></ruby>しい。

english: Weather; also “the weather is good/bad” as 天気がいい／悪い.
japanese_example: <ruby>今日<rt>きょう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>天気<rt>てんき</rt></ruby>がいい。

english: Means “to the extent/degree that …,” modifying a noun (often like “so … that …”). Typically: AいほどのN / VるほどのN.
japanese_example: <ruby>眩<rt>まぶ</rt></ruby>しいほどのいい<ruby>天気<rt>てんき</rt></ruby>だった。
english_example: The weather was so nice it was dazzling.

english: Lawn; turf; grass-covered ground (often in a yard or park).
japanese_example: <ruby>芝生<rt>しばふ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>座<rt>すわ</rt></ruby>る。

english: To cross; to cut across (a road, space, or area) from one side to the other.
japanese_example: <ruby>芝生<rt>しばふ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>横切<rt>よこぎ</rt></ruby>った。

english: Onomatopoeia for a heavy thud/plop, as when placing or dropping something with weight. Often used with 置く/落とす.
japanese_example: <ruby>鞄<rt>かばん</rt></ruby>をドサッと<ruby>置<rt>お</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: I plopped my bag down with a thud.

english: To hum; to softly sing/murmur a tune or words under one’s breath.
japanese_example: <ruby>歌<rt>うた</rt></ruby>を<ruby>口<rt>くち</rt></ruby>ずさむ。

english: Past tense of 口ずさむ: “hummed; softly sang/murmured (a tune/line).”
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>小<rt>ちい</rt></ruby>さな<ruby>歌<rt>うた</rt></ruby>を<ruby>口<rt>くち</rt></ruby>ずさんだ。
